questions.text: 67 years old female who had undergone a radical mastectomy now comes with the complaint of swelling and redness in her right upper limb. Involvement of which of the following structures explains these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Axillary group of LN Lymphoedema of the arm is a troublesome complication of breast cancer treatment, fortunately, seen less often now that radical axillary dissection and radiotherapy are rarely combined. However, it does still occur occasionally after either mode of treatment alone and appears at any time from months to years after treatment. There is usually no precipitating cause but recurrent tumors should be excluded because neoplastic infiltration of the axilla can cause arm swelling as a result of both lymphatic and venous blockage. So, lymph keeps on accumulating in the limb resulting in lymphoedema. This neoplastic infiltration is often painful because of brachial plexus nerve involvement.

Highyeild:

Lymphoedema: Lymphoedema may be defined as abnormal limb swelling caused by the accumulation of increased amounts of high protein ISF secondary to defective lymphatic drainage in the presence of (near) normal net capillary filtration Pathology: Result of an inability of the existing lymphatic system to accommodate the protein and fluid entering the interstitial compartment at the tissue level. Stages : First Stage - Soft pitting edema (impaired lymphatic drainage results in protein-rich fluid accumulation in the interstitial compartment) Second Stage - Nonpitting and Spongy consistency (the clinical condition is further exacerbated by the accumulation of fibroblasts, adipocytes, and, perhaps most important, macrophages in the affected tissues, which culminates in a local inflammatory response) Third Stage - Lymphostatic Elephantiasis (excessive subcutaneous fibrosis and scarring with associated severe skin change). Edema is irreversible at this stage. Aetiological classification of lymphoedema: Primary lymphoedema Congenital (onset <2 years old): sporadic; familial (Nonne–Milroy’s disease) Praecox (onset 2–35 years old): sporadic; familial (Letessier–Meige’s disease) Tarda (onset after 35 years old) Secondary lymphoedema A parasitic infection (filariasis) Fungal infection (tinea pedis) Exposure to foreign body material (silica particles) Primary malignancy Metastatic spread to lymph nodes Radiotherapy to lymph nodes Surgical excision of lymph nodes Trauma (particularly degloving injuries) Superficial thrombophlebitis Deep venous thrombosis. Diagnosis : Unlike other types of edema, lymphoedema characteristically involves the foot. The contour of the ankle is lost through infilling of the Sub malleolar depressions, A ‘buffalo hump’ forms on the dorsum of the foot, The toes appear ‘square’ because of the confinement of footwear and The skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched because of subcutaneous fibrosis (Stemmer’s sign) . Lymphoedema usually spreads proximally to knee level & less commonly affects the whole leg. Chronic eczema, fungal infection of the skin (dermatophytosis) and nails (onychomycosis), fissuring, verrucae, and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced diseases. Ulceration is unusual, except in the presence of chronic venous insufficiency Treatment: General Therapeutic Measures: Appropriate Antibiotics Maintenance of ideal body weight Elevation and Compression Garments: The ideal compression garment is custom fitted and delivers pressures in the range of 30 to 60 mm Hg. Limb Elevation at night Avoid standing for prolonged periods Complex Decongestive Physical Therapy Compression Pump Therapy (Pneumatic Compression therapy) Drug Therapy - Benzopyrones Molecular Lymphangiogenesis Operative Treatment: Reconstructive - should be considered for those patients with proximal (either primary or secondary) obstruction of the extremity lymphatic circulation with preserved, dilated lymphatics peripheral to the obstruction. Excisional - only viable option for patients without residual lymphatics of adequate size for reconstructive procedures. For patients with recalcitrant stage II and early stage III lymphedema in whom the edema is moderate and the skin is relatively healthy, an excisional procedure that removes a large segment of the lymphedematous subcutaneous tissues and the overlying skin is the procedure of choice

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A : Enlarged epitrochlear glands provide a useful discriminatory sign in the diagnosis of glandular fever Option B : Involvement of cephalic vein shows signs of deep vein thrombosis Option C : Radiation arteritis is a rare but serious complication following radiation therapy for the treatment of breast cancer

Extraedge:

Lymphedema is not curable, but the symptoms and long-term effects can be controlled with a combination of elastic compression stockings, limb elevation, pneumatic compression, and massage. Controlling the edema protects the skin and potentially prevents cellulitis

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman diagnosed with cancer in her left breast underwent a mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection. Postoperatively, she develops marked swelling of the left arm that has persisted for 6 months. Now on physical examination, her temperature is 36.9° C. Her left arm is not tender or erythematous, and it is not painful with movement or to touch, but it is enlarged with a doughy consistency. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymphedema The surgery disrupted lymphatic return, resulting in functional lymphatic obstruction and lymphedema of the arm. The lymphatic channels are important in scavenging fluid and protein that have leaked into the extravascular tissues from the intravascular compartment. Although the amount of fluid that is drained through the lymphatics is not great, it can build up gradually. Lymphoedema is a very common finding or complication seen in patients with breast cancer and after mastectomy .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A - Cellulitis is caused by an infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, and displays erythema, warmth, and tenderness. Option B - Congestive heart failure can lead to peripheral edema, which is most marked in dependent areas such as the lower extremities and over the sacrum (in bedridden patients). Option C - Decreased plasma oncotic pressure from hypoalbuminemia, or sodium and water retention with heart or renal failure, leads to more generalized edema.
